course.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a series of lessons in a particular subject
course.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Andy’s doing a one-year journalism course.
I’m taking a course in graphic design.
course.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a period of study in a particular subject, especially at university
course.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a period of time or process during which something happens
course.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: During the course of our conversation, it emerged that Bob had been in prison.
Over the course of the next few years, the steel industry was reorganized.
In the course of researching customer needs, we discovered how few families have adequate life insurance.
in the course of doing something
course.translation[0].definitions[3].def: the usual or natural way that something changes, develops, or is done
course.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Meeting Sally changed the whole course of his life.
Gorbachev changed the course of Soviet history.
In the normal course of events, a son would inherit from his father.
in the normal/natural/ordinary course of events
Relax and let nature take its course.
It seems the boom in World Music has run its course.
forces that shape the course of evolution
course.translation[0].definitions[4].def: the general plans someone has to achieve something or the general way something is happening
course.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: They will go to any lengths to get the White House to change course.
He will steer a middle course between pacifism and revolution.
As long as the economy stays on course, the future looks rosy.
course.translation[0].definitions[5].def: an action or series of actions that you could take in order to deal with a particular situation
course.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: I agreed that this was the only sensible course of action.
The judge took the only course of action open to him.
course.translation[0].definitions[6].def: the planned direction taken by a boat or plane to reach a place
course.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: The plane changed course to avoid the storm.
She tightened the mainsail while holding the course (=travelling in the same direction as planned).
The ship was blown off course.
The aircraft was almost ten miles off course.
course.translation[0].definitions[7].def: one of the separate parts of a meal
course.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: The ticket includes entry and a four-course meal.
We had fish for the main course.
course.translation[0].definitions[8].def: an area of land or water where races are held, or an area of land designed for playing golf
course.translation[0].definitions[9].def: an amount of medicine or medical treatment that you have regularly for a specific period of time
course.translation[0].definitions[10].de: the direction a river moves in
course.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: The course of the water was shown by a line of trees.
course.translation[0].definitions[11].de: a layer of bricks, stone etc in a wall
course.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: I decided to do a course in Italian.
My company wanted me to go on a course in management skills.
If you pass the course, you get a diploma in psychology.
The following year she applied for a nursing course.
enrol on a course/put your name down for a course
How about enrolling on a sailing course?
You’ll have to attend a course on how to deal with customers on the phone.
withdraw from a course/drop out of a course
She had to withdraw from the course because of illness.
She is teaching an introductory course in Russian.
The course is run by the British Council.
The course is offered on a part-time basis.
Some students choose to change their course after the first year.
The school runs ten-week language courses three times a year.
There are also part-time courses for mature students.
an advanced course in art and design
She did a one-year teacher training course.
I did a short course on website design.
An intensive course in Russian is provided for those who do not already know the language.
A husband was given a crash course in how to deliver a baby by a midwife on the phone.
If you are offered the job, you will attend a two-week training course.
students who fail their college courses
a tailor-made course to help senior staff develop their negotiation skills
I discussed it with my course tutor.
Teachers are provided with course material.
The school has recently introduced a new course syllabus.
course.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 5: the usual or natural way that something changes, develops, or is done
course.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: He felt that events were taking the wrong course.
There was nothing we could do except watch the illness run its course.
The incident changed the course of the election.
The result of this battle influenced the whole course of the war.
Don’t let chance decide the course of your career.
in the normal/ordinary course of something
His bravery was far more than was required in the normal course of duty.
the course of history/somebody’s life etc
Changing  conditions shape the course of evolution.
course.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if a liquid or electricity courses somewhere, it flows there quickly
course.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if a feeling courses through you, you feel it suddenly and strongly
course.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: His smile sent waves of excitement coursing through her.
course.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to chase rabbits with dogs as a sport
course.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a series of classes or studies in a particular subject
